children: A 35-year-old man is evaluated for loss of peripheral vision discovered during a comprehensive ophthalmologic examination. The patient is asymptomatic and has 20/20 visual acuity in both eyes.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is glaucoma. This fundoscopic image shows a relatively large cup-to-disc ratio of >0.5 and cupping, identified by the disappearance of vessels over the edge of the attenuated optic rim. The normal optic disc is slightly oval in the vertical meridian and is pink in color, as
. A central depression on the surface of the disc is called the physiological cup. Typically, this cup-to-disc ratio is less than 0.5. The optic discs of the eyes should appear similar and symmetric.

Funduscopic findings in glaucoma include vertical extension of the central cup, disc hemorrhages, and an increased optic cup-to-disc ratio (>0.5). All of these findings are nonspecific, however, and may be seen in patients without glaucoma. Glaucoma is the leading cause of permanent blindness in the world. It is typically characterized by increased intraocular pressure as a result of decreased outflow of aqueous humor from the anterior chamber. If central vision is not lost, patients can maintain normal visual acuity, potentially delaying diagnosis.
